questions.prompt: British values and principles are based on history and traditions and are protected by law, customs and expectations.
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: When did the first Christian communities begin to appear in Britain?
questions.explanation: It was during the 3rd and 4th centuries AD that the first Christian communities began to appear in Britain.

questions.prompt: Which of the following is NOT a devolved administration?
questions.explanation: There are three devolved administrations in the UK, this include: the Welsh Assembly, the Scottish Parliament and the Northern Ireland Assembly.

questions.prompt: Who built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people)?
questions.explanation: Areas of what is now Scotland were never conquered by the Romans, and the Emperor Hadrien built a wall in the north of England to keep out the Picts (ancestors of the Scottish people).

questions.prompt: Who looks after Edinburgh Castle?
questions.explanation: Edinburgh castle is a dominant feature of the skyline in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has a long history, dating back to the early Middle Ages. It is looked after by Historic Environment Scotland.

questions.prompt: Each MP represents a parliamentary constituency, which is a small area of the country:
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: Who were the pioneers of the IVF (in-vitro fertilisation) therapy?
options: Sir Frank Whittle and Sir Christopher Cockrell
Sir Robert Edwards and Patrick Steptoe
Francis Creek and John Logie Baird
Sir Ian Wilmot and Keith Campbell
questions.explanation: IVF (in-vitro fertilisation) therapy for the treatment of infertility was pioneered in Britain by physiologist Sir Robert Edwards (1925-) and gynaecologist Patrick Steptoe (1913-88). The world’s first ‘test-tube baby’ was born in Oldham, Lancashire in 1978.

questions.prompt: Who led the establishment of the National Health System (NHS) in 1948?
questions.explanation: In 1948, Aneurin (Nye) Bevan, the Minister for Health, led the establishment of the National Health Service (NHS), which guaranteed a minimum standard of health care for all, free at the point of use.

questions.prompt: Which of the following countries were granted their independence in 1947 (choose THREE answers)?
questions.explanation: In 1947, independence was granted to nine countries, including India, Pakistan and Ceylon (now Sri Lanka).

questions.prompt: In the UK, bank holidays of no religious significance are celebrated at the beginning of May, in late May or early June, and in August:
questions.explanation: This statement is true.

questions.prompt: Where can Admiral Nelson’s ship known as HMS Victory be visited?
questions.explanation: Admiral Nelson’s ship, HMS Victory, can be visited in Portsmouth.

questions.prompt: Who were the Puritans?
options: A group of Catholics who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship
A group of Protestants who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship
A group of landowners from the 18th century
A group of local leaders that surged in Wales with strict religious views
questions.explanation: The Puritans were a group of Protestants who advocated strict and simple religious doctrine and worship. They did not agree with the king’s religious views and disliked his reforms of the Church of England.

questions.prompt: What TWO different types of rugby are practised in the UK?
questions.explanation: There are two different types of rugby, which have different rules: union and league.

questions.prompt: What do William Blake, John Keats and Lord Byron have in common?
options: They were British poets of the 19th century
They were British painters of the Swinging Sixties
They were musicians of the middle ages
questions.explanation: Poetry was very popular in the 19th century, with poets such as William Blake, John Keats, Lord Byron, Percy Shelley, Alfred Lord Tennyson, and Robert and Elizabeth Browning.

questions.prompt: The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues in Liverpool:
questions.explanation: The Laurence Olivier Awards take place annually at different venues in London.

questions.prompt: An additional rented piece of land where people can grow fruit and vegetables is known as:
questions.explanation: In the UK, some people rent additional land called ‘an allotment’, where they grow fruit and vegetables.

questions.prompt: What is the name of the battle where the Scottish led by Robert the Bruce defeated the English in 1314?
questions.explanation: In 1314 the Scottish, led by Robert the Bruce, defeated the English at the Battle of Bannockburn.

questions.prompt: Who took the English throne after the death of Henry VIII?
questions.explanation: Henry VIII was succeeded by his son Edward VI.

questions.prompt: Carrying a weapon is a criminal offence, unless it is for self-defence:
questions.explanation: It is a criminal offence to carry a weapon of any kind, even if it is for self-defence. This includes a gun, a knife or anything that is made or adapted to cause injury.

questions.prompt: Prohibition of thought, conscience and religion is one of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights:
questions.explanation: Freedom of thought, conscience and religion is one of the principles included in the European Convention of Human Rights

questions.prompt: Which TWO pop music groups became popular in the 1960s?
questions.explanation: Two well-known pop music groups in the 1960s were The Beatles and The Rolling Stones.

questions.prompt: Which of the following words comes from the Viking language?
questions.explanation: Words such as Grimsby and Scunthorpe come from the Viking languages.

questions.prompt: Eid ul Adha is the day when Muslims thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast:
questions.explanation: The day when Muslims thank Allah for giving them the strength to complete the fast is called Eid a-Fitr.

questions.prompt: Will a non-UK national living in the UK and looking for work, starting work or setting up as self-employed need a National Insurance number?
questions.explanation: A non-UK national living in the UK and looking for work, starting work or setting up as self-employed will need a National Insurance number. However, you can start work without one.
